au.com.innodev.wmboost.data

Interface Document


  • public interface Document
    Represents a document that contains key/value entries, as an abstraction of webMethods' IData.

    Allows easy access and manipulation of an IData document. It provides a simplified mechanism to deal with aspects such as type conversion and determining whether entries are present, while providing more predictable behaviour than some IDataUtil methods, such as IDataUtil.getBoolean(com.wm.data.IDataCursor).

    It also provides easier abstraction for manipulation of collection values and nested documents.

    The following example shows how one can use it to implement a service that adds two integer values: 

     public static final void addInts(IData pipeline) throws ServiceException {
        Document pipeDoc = Documents.wrap(pipeline);
        Integer number1 = pipeDoc.intEntry("number1").getNonNullVal();
        Integer number2 = pipeDoc.intEntry("number2").getNonNullVal();
 
        Integer result = number1 + number2;
        pipeDoc.intEntry("result").put(result);
 }
    The example highlights some important features:
    • There's no need to retrieve and destroy IDataCursor instances
    • The numbers are retrieved in a way that ensures both that values exist in the pipeline document and that they are non-null. There's no need for associated if statements.
    • Automatic conversion to Integer is performed for the input numbers. For instance, if number1 was actually stored as a string, it would automatically be converted to an integer. Similarly, if a value of Long, BigDecimal or similar had been found, the conversion would've been done automatically.
    • It's possible to return the result as an integer as shown in the example. If one wanted to return a string, then one would call pipelineDoc.stringEntry("result").putConverted(result) and the integer value would be automatically converted to String.

    Automatic Conversion

    The automatic type conversion depends on the configuration defined while creating the document through the originating DocumentFactory. Out-of-box conversions include:

    • String to boolean: values such as "true", "false", "yes", "no" are converted. In order to ensure predictability, unsupported string values such as "maybe" throw an exception. Contrast this with the implementation of IDataUtil.getBoolean(com.wm.data.IDataCursor), which returns false.
    • String to numbers, such as Integer, Long, BigDecimal, etc. and vice-versa
    • Numbers to numbers: such as Integer to Long
    • Strings to enumerations and vice versa
    • etc.
    All conversions are internally performed by an instance of Spring's ConversionService. The DocumentFactory that created the document instance determines the conversion service to be used.

    Implementation

    An internal implementation for this Document interface is provided.

    Thread-safety is not guaranteed by implementations of this interface and the associated entry interfaces.

    See Also:
    Documents

    • Method Detail

      • containsKey

        boolean containsKey(String key)
        Returns whether the provided key exists in at least one of the document entries.
        Parameters:
        key - name of the key
        Returns:
        true if an entry with the key exists; false, otherwise

      • getKeys

        Collection<String> getKeys()
        Returns a set of keys contained in the document.

        Even if multiple entries existed for a particular key, that key would be returned only once.

        Returns:
        a read-only set of keys that correspond to the document entries

      • isEmpty

        boolean isEmpty()
        Returns true if the document has no entries.
        Returns:
        true if empty; false otherwise

      • getTotalEntries

        int getTotalEntries()
        Returns the number of all entries.

        If each key is unique in the document (which is the most common case), then this method returns the same number as the size of elements in getKeys().

        However, for certain documents, such as deserialised XML content with lists, more than one entry per key may exist. In those cases, the returned value will be greater than the size of getKeys().

        Returns:
        the number of entries in the document

      • getAllEntries

        EntryIterableResource getAllEntries()
        Returns all document entries, including multiple entries sharing the same key (i.e. split entries).

        The number of returned elements matches the one given by getTotalEntries().

        Note that the returned value is both an Iterable and a Closeable. This means that the close() method needs to be invoked after processing is complete.

        In Java 7 or higher it can be used in a foreach loop but it needs to be surrounded by a try-with-resources block.

        Java 7 or Higher Example 

         try (EntryIterableResource entries = document.getAllEntries()) {
         for (KeyValue entry : entries) {
                // do something
         }
 }

        Java 6 Example 

         EntryIterableResource entries = document.getAllEntries();
 try {
        while (entries.hasNext()) {
                KeyValue entry = entries.next();
                // do something
        }
 } finally {
        entries.close();
 }
        Returns:
        an iterable resource containing all entries

      • getUnitEntries

        Iterable<KeyValue> getUnitEntries()
        Returns unit entries in the document. If multiple entries exist for a given key, only the first entry is retrieved for that key.

        Note that this method is consistent with entry(String, Class) and its variations.

        The number of returned elements is the same as the size of getKeys().

        Returns:
        unit entries

      • clear

        void clear()
        Removes all document entries

      • getIData

        com.wm.data.IData getIData()
        Retrieves the underlying IData instance that this document is wrapping.

        Since a Document always acts on an IData, the value returned by this method is never null.

        Returns:
        the underlying IData instance

      • entry

        <T> ItemEntry<T> entry(String key,
                       Class<T> type)
        Returns a reference to a single entry identified by the key.

        Through this reference, the entry value can be retrieved, set or removed.

        When a value is returned, it is checked to be of type T. If it isn't, a conversion is performed. If that conversion fails, an exception is thrown.

        Use this method for types for which convenience methods haven't been defined. stringEntry(String) is recommended for string entries. However, this method is suitable for types such as enums, special types such as AtomicInteger and File. Domain objects (e.g. a Client object) are also supported but no out-of-the-box conversion is provided for them.

        For example, to retrieve an automatically-converted value of a custom Enum such as RoundingMode, you may use the following code: 

         import java.math.RoundingMode;
 //...
 RoundingMode mode = document.entry("roundingMode", RoundingMode.class).getNonNullVal();

        Note that this and similar methods operate on a unit entry. If there were multiple entries associated to the key, only the first one would be referenced. This behaviour supports typical use cases; for situations where multiple entries for a key may exist and processing is required for all those entries, use of splitEntry(String, Class) would be more appropriate.

        Type Parameters:
        T - type of the value component of the document entry
        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the document entry
        type - type of the value component of the document entry
        Returns:
        an entry reference
        See Also:
        ItemEntry

      • entry

        ItemEntry<Object> entry(String key)
        Returns a reference to an entry. Use it when you don't know have an assumption about the type of the entry's value or for other special cases.
        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the document entry
        Returns:
        an entry reference
        See Also:
        entry(String, Class)

      • docEntry

        NestedDocEntry docEntry(String key)
        Returns a reference to an entry with a nested document as the value.

        Note that because Document is just an abstraction, the value is internally stored as an IData instance, as expected by webMethods.

        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the document entry
        Returns:
        an entry reference
        See Also:

      • collectionEntry

        <E> CollectionEntry<E> collectionEntry(String key,
                                       Class<E> memberType)
        Returns a reference to an entry identified by the key and whose value is a collection.

        Through this reference, the entry value can be retrieved, set or removed.

        When a value is returned, it is checked to be of a collection of type instances. If it isn't, a conversion is performed. If that conversion fails, an exception is thrown.

        Note that this method operates on a unit entry (albeit that entry's value is a collection). If there were multiple entries associated to the key, only the first one would be referenced. This behaviour supports typical use cases; for situations where multiple entries per key are expected, use splitEntry(String, Class) instead.

        Type Parameters:
        E - type of the elements in a collection in the value component of the document entry
        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the document entry
        memberType - type of the elements in a collection in the value component of the document entry
        Returns:
        an entry reference
        See Also:
        CollectionEntry

      • collectionEntry

        CollectionEntry<Object> collectionEntry(String key)
        Returns a reference to an entry with a value treated as a collection of objects. Use it when you don't know have an assumption about the type of the elements in the entry's value or for other special cases.
        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the document entry
        Returns:
        an entry reference
        See Also:
        entry(String, Class)

      • splitEntry

        <E> SplitEntry<E> splitEntry(String key,
                             Class<E> memberType)
        Returns a reference to a split entry.

        Through this reference, the split entry value can be retrieved, set or removed.

        As opposed to entry(String, Class), a split entry handles all values associated wit a key, even if the key is shared across multiple entries.

        When a value is returned, all of the elements are checked to be of type T. If it isn't, a conversion is performed. If that conversion fails, an exception is thrown.

        Type Parameters:
        E - memberType
        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the split entry
        memberType - type of each individual entry that makes up a split entry
        Returns:
        a split entry reference

      • splitEntry

        SplitEntry<Object> splitEntry(String key)
        Returns a reference to a split entry. Use it when you don't know have an assumption about the type of the entry's value or for other special cases.
        Parameters:
        key - key that identifies the split entry
        Returns:
        a split entry reference
